{{Spanish name|Mir|Vicente}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Rafa Mir | image = | caption = | image_size = | fullname = Rafael Mir Vicente | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1997|6|18|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Murcia]], Spain | height = 1.89 m | position = [[Forward (association football)|Forward]] | currentclub = [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]]
(on loan from [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]) | clubnumber = 9 | youthyears1 = | youthclubs1 = Javalí Nuevo | youthyears2 = 2006–2007 | youthclubs2 = [[ElPozo Murcia FS|ElPozo Murcia]] | youthyears3 = 2007–2009 | youthclubs3 = Ranero | youthyears4 = 2009–2011 | youthclubs4 = [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]] | youthyears5 = 2011–2012 | youthclubs5 = [[Real Murcia|Murcia]] | youthyears6 = 2012–2016 | youthclubs6 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | years1 = 2015–2018 | clubs1 = [[Valencia CF Mestalla|Valencia B]] | caps1 = 60| goals1 = 25 | years2 = 2015–2018 | clubs2 = [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] | caps2 = 2 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] | caps3 = 2 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[UD Las Palmas|Las Palmas]] (loan) | caps4 = 18 | goals4 = 5 | nationalyears1 = 2018– | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spain U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 6 | nationalgoals1 = 5 | medaltemplates = | club-update = 11 October 2018 | nationalteam-update = 19 November 2018 }} '''Rafael "Rafa" Mir Vicente''' (born 18 June 1997) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] for [[UD Las Palmas]], on loan from English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]]. ==Club career== ===Youth career=== Born in [[Murcia]], Mir began his career playing [[futsal]] with CD Javalí Nuevo. After a 120-goal spell at [[ElPozo Murcia FS]] he began playing full football with Ranero CF, scoring 57 and 84 goals in his respective seasons before joining [[FC Barcelona]]. Mir's 32 goals at [[La Masia]] earned him a return to his [[Region of Murcia|native region]] and [[Real Murcia]], where a 45-goal haul led to the attention of [[Valencia CF]]. He made his senior debut for [[Valencia CF Mestalla|the reserves]] on 1 March 2015, as an 88th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for [[Wilfried Zahibo]] in a 2–1 [[Segunda División B]] loss at [[CE L'Hospitalet]]. ===Valencia=== Mir scored his first senior goal on 7 March 2015, netting the last in a 2–0 win over [[CF Badalona]] at the [[Ciudad Deportiva de Paterna]].{{cite news|title=El Mestalla sufre pero se impone|trans-title=Mestalla suffer but impose themselves|url=http://www.levante-emv.com/deportes/2015/03/09/mestalla-sufre-impone/1236033.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=Levante EMV|date=9 March 2015|language=Spanish}} He finished [[2014–15 Segunda División B|the campaign]] with four appearances, as his side narrowly avoided relegation. The following season, Mir excelled in the [[UEFA Youth League]], scoring consecutive braces in victories over [[K.A.A. Gent]].{{cite news|title=Perfect Arsenal forge on in Youth League|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2295564.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=20 October 2015}}{{cite news|title=Holders Chelsea assured of top-two finish|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2301040.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=4 November 2015}} On 14 November 2015, he was given his first start for the B-side, playing the full 90 minutes in a 2–4 loss at another [[reserve team]], [[Villarreal CF B]].{{cite news|title=El Valencia Mestalla naufraga ante el Villarreal B|trans-title=Valencia Mestalla sink against Villarreal B|url=http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2015/11/14/sigue--villarreal-b-/276272.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=Super Deporte|date=14 November 2015|language=Spanish}} On 24 November 2015, Mir was called up to the main squad by manager [[Nuno Espírito Santo]] for a [[La Liga]] game against [[UD Las Palmas]];{{cite news|last1=Gimeno|first1=Manu|title=Nuno se lleva a Rafa Mir y recupera a pesos pesados|trans-title=Nuno brings in Rafa Mir and regains heavyweights|url=http://valencia.eldesmarque.com/valencia-cf/noticias/8576-convocatoria-valencia-las-palmas-nuno-se-lleva-a-rafa-mir|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=El Desmarque|date=20 November 2015|language=Spanish}} he was an unused substitute in the 1–1 draw at the [[Mestalla Stadium]].{{cite news|title=Viera gets the point for Las Palmas as Valencia are left frustrated|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/spanish-primera-division/match/433862/valencia-las-palmas/report|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=ESPN|date=21 November 2015}} He made his professional debut on 25 November, starting in a [[UEFA Champions League]] group stage match away to [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]],{{cite news|last1=Rocha Rodrigues|first1=Luís|last2=Sousa|first2=Vasco|title=Para sacudir a crise, Nuno estreia Rafa Mir, de 18 anos|trans-title=To end the crisis, Nuno chooses, Rafa Mir, 18|url=http://www.zerozero.pt/news.php?id=165227|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=ZeroZero|date=24 November 2015|language=Portuguese}} being substituted for [[Santi Mina]] in the 56th minute of an eventual 2–0 defeat.{{cite news|title=Zenit stay perfect at Valencia's expense|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000634/match=2015735/postmatch/report/index.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=24 November 2015}} He made his top-flight debut against Las Palmas on 28 August, replacing [[Enzo Pérez]] for the final four minutes of a 2–4 home loss.{{cite news|title=El Las Palmas desnuda al Valencia|trans-title=Las Palmas expose Valencia|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/deportes/las-palmas-desnuda-valencia-5339074|accessdate=19 September 2016|publisher=El Periódico|date=23 August 2016|language=Spanish}} Mir began the first half of the 2017–18 season for Valencia B in good form, scoring 15 goals in 19 games, attracting interest from [[Real Madrid]] and [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11699/11194410/wolves-close-to-signing-rafa-mir-from-valencia|title=Wolves close to signing Rafa Mir from Valencia|publisher=Sky Sports|date=3 January 2018}} ===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 3 January 2018, Mir joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] for an undisclosed fee, signing a four-and-a-half-year contract with the club and taking the number 9 shirt.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180103-welcome-rafa/|title=Welcome Rafa|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers Football Club|date=3 January 2018}} He links up with former Valencia boss [[Nuno Espírito Santo]], who gave him his first team debut at the club. ====Las Palmas (loan)==== On 23 July 2018, Mir joined [[Segunda División]] side [[UD Las Palmas]] on loan for one season.{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180723-mir-departs-molineux-on-loan/|title=Mir Departs Molineux On Loan|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers FC|date=23 July 2018|access-date=23 July 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 6 January 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/rafael-mir-vicente/398451/|title=Rafa Mir Statistics|work=soccerway|accessdate=3 January 2018}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan="2"|Club !rowspan="2"|Season !rowspan="2"|Division !colspan="2"|League !colspan="2"|National Cup !colspan="2"|[[EFL Cup]] !colspan="2"|Total |- !Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan="5"|[[Valencia CF Mestalla|Valencia B]] |2||0||colspan="2"|—||colspan="2"|—||2||0 |- |[[2016–17 Segunda División B|2016–17]] |[[Segunda División B]] |35||9||colspan="2"|—||colspan="2"|—||35||9 |- |[[2017–18 Segunda División B|2017–18]] |[[Segunda División B]] |19||15||colspan="2"|—||colspan="2"|—||19||15 |- !colspan="2"|Total !60!!25!!0!!0!!0!!0!!60!!25 |- |rowspan="3"|[[Valencia CF|Valencia]] |[[2015–16 La Liga|2015–16]] |[[La Liga]] |0||0||1||0||colspan="2"|—||1||0 |- |[[2016–17 La Liga|2016–17]] |[[La Liga]] |2||0||3||0||colspan="2"|—||5||0 |- !colspan="2"|Total !2!!0!!4!!0!!0!!0!!6!!0 |- |rowspan="1"|[[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] |[[2017–18 Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C. season|2017–18]] |[[EFL Championship|Championship]] |2||0||2||0||colspan="2"|—||4||0 |- !colspan="3"|Career Total !62!!25!!5!!0!!0!!0!!67!!25 |} ==Personal life== Mir, who idolised German forward [[Mario Gómez]], is the son of former defender [[Magín Mir]], whose clubs included [[RCD Mallorca]] and Murcia.{{cite news|title=Rafa Mir, el ´gigante´ de los mil goles del Valencia CF|trans-title=Rafa Mir, Valencia CF's 1000-goal 'giant'|url=http://www.superdeporte.es/valencia/2015/11/10/rafa-mir-gigante-mil-goles/275802.html|accessdate=24 November 2015|publisher=Superdeporte|date=11 November 2015|language=Spanish}}
